explanation:
OS_CHECK_POINTER: Macro invoked at the top of the function. Must inspect its expansion to ensure it does not contain any for-statements (or otherwise inject a for loop) and to see if it has persistent side effects relevant to MISRA for-loop clause 2.

OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: Macro used to obtain 'record' from the global table. Its expansion may contain indexing logic or for-loops or calls (e.g. via OS_ObjectIndexFromToken); must be checked for any for statements or modifications of loop counters if expanded inline.

OS_global_stream_table: The object passed into OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET. Its type/definition may determine whether OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET expansion iterates over the table (for-loops) or uses indexing; needed to analyse any loop constructs introduced by the macro.

OS_common_record_t: Type of 'record'. Required to inspect the definition (members such as name_entry and creator) to determine whether accessing record->name_entry or record->creator involves macros or inline code that could include for loops.

OS_socket_prop_t: Type of 'sock_prop'. Needed to examine its 'name' member (size and whether it is a macro or accessor) and to check if any member access expands to code containing for-loops or persistent side effects.

OS_object_token_t: Type of 'token'. Included because macros/functions that operate on the token (e.g. OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET or OS_ObjectIndexFromToken) might use it and introduce loops; definition may reveal inline helpers.

OS_ObjectIdGetById: Called before any table access. Its implementation may be a macro/inline or call other symbols that could introduce for loops if inlined; need to confirm it does not inject a for loop into this function's flow.

OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Present in the static-call graph and commonly used by table/index macros. If OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET or other inlines call this, it may contain for-loops; include to inspect any loop constructs introduced via indexing.

OS_ObjectIdRelease: Called at function end. Its implementation might be a macro/inline containing loops; must be checked to ensure it does not introduce malformed for loops into this function.

OS_SocketGetInfo_Impl: Called while holding the token. Although it is a separate function, if it is inlined (macro/static inline) or the codebase policy considers called functions' internals for counting for-loops, its body should be checked for any for statements that could affect compliance when regarded as part of the function behaviour.

memset: Standard library function called here. Typically not inlined with a for loop in the source under analysis, but include to confirm no macro replacement or inline implementation introduces a for-statement into this translation unit.

strncpy: Standard library function used to copy the name. As with memset, ensure there is no macro or inline replacement in this build that would inject a for loop into the containing function.

OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_SUCCESS: Symbolic constants used as arguments/return checks. Their values do not themselves cause for-loops, but their definitions should be checked only to confirm they are simple constants/macros and not complex macros that expand into code containing for-loops or persistent side effects.

Rationale summary: The MISRA rule applies to for-statements present in the function; even if the source text has no explicit for, macros or inlined constructs (e.g. OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_ObjectIdRelease) can introduce for-statements into the compiled function. The listed symbols cover all macros, inline helpers, types, and called routines whose definitions/expansions could introduce for-loops or side effects relevant to the three clauses (loop counter initialization, test, and increment) and must be examined to determine compliance.
